courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Introduction to Learning Sciences
courses.description: This course provides an overview of basic concepts and theories of learning sciences.First, concepts and theories of cognitive psychology related to learning are introduced, including but not limited to attention, language processing, working memory, long-term memory, meaningful learning, constructivism, knowledge representation, memory processes of encoding, retrieval, and forgetting.Second, evidence-based instructional strategies and principles based on research in learning sciences are discussed, such as attention/memory training, flipped classroom, speed reading, learning styles, game-based learning, feedback, worked examples, spacing and interleaving, influence of mood and anxiety, metacognition and self-regulation, and practice testing.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. demonstrate an understanding of psychological theories of learning sciences and their relationship with instructional practices

2. describe, analyze, and evaluate evidence-based instructional strategies and/or principles based on research in learning sciences

3. apply effective evidence-based instructional strategies to foster students' learning

(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

完成本科後，學生應該能夠：

1. 展示對學習科學的心理學理論及其與教學實踐的關係的理解

2. 描述、分析和評估基於學習科學的研究和以實證為基礎的教學策略和原則

3. 應用有效而以實證為基礎的教學策略來促進學生的學習

（個別科目教師可在必要時更新學習成果。）
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Course introduction; Basic concepts of learning sciences

Week 2: Cognitive theories of learning sciences

Week 3: Attention, memory, and cognitive training

Week 4: Language processing, text comprehension, and speed reading

Week 5: Desirable difficulty and feedback

Week 6: Worked examples and analogical reasoning

Week 7: Emotion, anxiety, and cognition

Week 8: Cognitive load, multimedia, and game-based learning

Week 9: Metacognition, self-regulated learning, and flipped classroom

Week 10: Spacing and Interleaving

Week 11: Practice testing

Week 12: Group presentation

Week 13: Wrap up

(Individual course teachers may update the course syllabus as and whenever necessary.)

courses.title: Learning Design in New and Emerging Educational Contexts
courses.description: This course aims to discuss what, why and how learning design elements can/ should be incorporated in learning environments to support effective learning in new and emerging educational contexts. Particularly, the focus of the course will be on examining the integration of learning design principles and approaches in accordance with the educational goals of the twenty-first century.

courses.title: Educational Analytics
courses.description: Analysis of learner data provides valuable insight into learning processes to understand and optimize learning environments. This enables universities, schools, and training organizations to improve the quality and overall efficiency of learning. This course will provide an introduction to analytics in learning and how it is being deployed in various contexts in education, including to inform educators, and to promote scientific discovery. Students will explore the logic of analytics, the basics of cleaning and using educational data, context analysis, and predictive models. This course will also discuss tools and analytics methods that educators need, and how to protect learner privacy and other rights.

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Design Thinking as Scientific Inquiry
courses.description: Design thinking as scientific inquiry is an innovative approach for developing user-centered innovative solutions in business and society. This course will discuss design thinking principles such as user participation, problem framing, prototype making, experimentation and evaluation, visualization and diversity, which are essential skills for management and innovation. It will also discuss how design thinking drives innovation and solves some of the most global and local complex problems, for example, develop new product/service development, and address strategic, operational, organizational and social issues. Upon completion, students are able to apply design thinking to their own situations and organizations, and plan for how to embed this type of thinking to drive innovation.

courses.description: A digital citizen is a person who develops the skills, literacy, competence to safely and effectively use the internet and digital technologies. Students will design, develop, and evaluate a digital citizenship program is used by individuals, nonprofits, schools, and governments all over the world.

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Leading Innovations in Organizations in the Era of Globalization
courses.description: This course aims to provide a broad understanding of the importance of innovation to organizations and the role of innovative leadership in the contemporary society. Various types of innovation and models of organizations and leadership will be explored to elucidate their inter-relationships. Students will have an opportunity to examine the characteristics of innovative learning organizations with real-life examples including the organizational structure, culture and leadership strategies for organizational change. Key processes of organizational learning, teamwork, strategic development and knowledge management will be analyzed in specific contexts. Through reviewing a range of literature and applying it to multiple scenarios, students are encouraged to integrate theory with practice and develop their leadership capacity for driving innovation in different organizational settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
The core contents that will be covered include the following:

1. The importance of innovation to organizations in the contemporary society under the influence of globalization

2. The meanings and drivers of innovation, and its major types (e.g. technological innovation and process innovation)

3. Theories of learning organizations, models of leadership and their relationships with innovation

4. Organizational structure, culture, capacity and strategy for organizational change

5. Team building and communities of practice

6. Intellectual capital (e.g. human capital, structural capital, relationship capital) that facilitates innovation

7. Cultivating partnerships and networks for innovation

8. Knowledge management, knowledge transfer, knowledge sharing and their relationship with innovation

Students will also be exposed to real-life examples in various forms (e.g. case studies, field visits, news reporting) and engaged in active discussion on the dynamic relationship among innovation, organizational learning capacity, and leadership.

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Educational Design Research (Research Method)
courses.description: This course aims to provide an overview on various research methods (qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods) used in educational research and prepare students to conduct their own research project. The course will go through the steps in designing research topic and questions, searching and reviewing relevant literature, formulating research hypotheses, identifying suitable research tools and sampling methods, analyzing and interpreting research findings and writing up research reports with students. Students will also learn the principles of research ethics and procedures in obtaining ethics clearance at CUHK.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. demonstrate an understanding of the basic principles of research methods in the area of educational design and technology

2. conduct literature search and review, identify research gaps for a selected research topic and formulate relevant hypotheses

3. determine the suitable research tools and data collection methods to address the proposed research questions;

4. analyze and interpret collected data and prepare a structured research report

5. explain the principles of research ethics and complete the CUHK ethics clearance procedures

(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

完成本科後，學生應該能夠：

1. 展示對教育設計和技術領域研究方法的基本原理的理解

2. 進行文獻檢索和評論，辨認研究課題中的研究缺口並提出相關假設

3. 確定合適的研究工具和數據收集方法來解決擬議的研究問題

4. 分析和解釋數據並將之撰寫成研究報告

5. 解釋研究倫理原則並完成中大倫理審查程序

Week 9: Quantitative research: experimental design

Week 10: Psychonomic, educational neuroscience and the latest research paradigm in learning sciences

Week 12: Data interpretation and research report

Week 13: Revision and summary

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Educational Innovation and Society: A Comparative Perspective
courses.description: Educational innovation can be found in processes, services, programmes and partnerships. Educational innovation improves teaching and learning, enhances wellbeing, ensures successful transitions and pathways, as well as alleviates inequity. This course will start with an introduction on the role of education in economic development followed by discussion on various forms of educational innovation in schooling systems including alternative schools. Case studies on innovative educational practice in different countries will be examined. Students will be asked to identify educational challenges that learners and teachers are grappling with. Guest lectures are offered by leaders of local or international social enterprises and foundations that practice and support educational innovations. Students will be invited to brainstorm and join social enterprises’ efforts to provide sustainable strategies to tackle development issues especially to that of educational equality. Evaluation on how educational innovations promote student learning will also be explored. At the end of the course, students will develop a proposal that advances current educational practices in our society reflecting community needs and addressing the social inequality and poverty issues.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is aimed to help students develop an understanding of the contributions of educational innovation in economic development by improving educational opportunity and inspire them to create new or advance an existing educational innovation. Specifically the course will:

1. Familiarize students with the contributions of education entrepreneurs to innovation in a comparative perspective.

2. Provide students the opportunity to meet leaders of local or international social enterprises and foundations that practice and support educational innovations and to critically analyze innovative organizations or programs in education.

3. Engage students in the analysis of cases examining how innovative solutions are produced to social problems.

4. Build up targeted skill sets that prepare students to understand the logic of starting up and sustaining a social enterprise.

5. Create among the students a peer-supporting community for those who own entrepreneurship skills, a passion for harnessing innovation and creativity to improve educational outcomes for all learners.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction

Week 2: The role of Education in Economic Development

Week 3: Educational Innovation and Entrepreneurship in education

Week 4: Entrepreneurial education: effects and practices

Week 5 -8: Guest lectures offered by leaders of local or international social enterprises and foundations; Case studies

Week 9: Interview of guest lecturers

Week 10: Writing of Problem Statement

Week 11-12: Summary and group consultations

Week 13: Group presentation and video-pitch

The final group presentations contains a 1-minute video-pitch that solves as well as a 10 minutes presentation in Pecha Kucha format (please see details below).

Students are asked to record one-minute video-pitch that provides an innovative and sustainable solution for a particular education-related issue that they identified for the partnered-organizations/social venture.

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Education, Technology and Human Development
courses.description: This course provides an introductory survey of the links between education, technological advancement and human development in the globe. While digital and technological innovation accelerates economic growth and plays a critical role for reducing poverty, it also trigger social inequality issues. Further, technological changes (such as computerization, artificial intelligence, etc.) will fundamentally alter the nature of professions and of high skilled jobs generally. The course starts with an overview of the current educational attainment and schooling investments across the world. This is followed by exploring the demand for human capital and educational investments aligned with economic development, public financing of education. Students will also be able to examine interactions between education, technology and development from social and economic perspectives on other issues, including compulsory education reform, manpower planning and curriculum reform, automation and its impact on jobs and labor market, gender gap in schooling and STEM subjects, welfare policy reforms and its impact on children.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn about important concepts and perspectives in education and human development.

2. Develop a critical understanding of the complexity and variation in cross-national response to human capital investment based on development stages and under the influence of technological innovation and artificial intelligence.

3. Learn to identify and critique the education policies with reference to socio-economic development.

4. Discuss strategies for achieving inclusive growth and reducing human poverty and extreme inequality
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction

Week 2: Global Landscape of Education

Week 3: Human Capital and Demand of Education

Week 4: Human Development and its Measurement

Week 5: The role of education and technology in economic growth

Week 6: Technology, Changing Nature of Work and Impact on Education

Week 7: Educational reforms: curriculum, teaching and learning

Week 8: Gender gap in schooling and STEM subjects

Week 9: Digital technologies, household welfare, and its impact on children

Week 10: Technology, Vocational Education and Higher education development

Week 11-12: Project presentations

Week 13: Summary

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Instructional Design for Students with SEN in Technology-Supported Learning Environments
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with fundamental knowledge of selected areas of special needs (learning disabilities, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit / hyperactivity disorder, emotional and behavioral disorder, and giftedness) and help them to understand possible learning difficulties children with these special needs would encounter. For each kind of special need, students will learn its characteristics, causes, and provision of special education in Hong Kong. Besides, this course will also prepare students for designing effective solutions using technology for children with learning, literacy, and cognitive challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EDUC4340.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester, students should be able to:

1. describe the characteristics of various types of special-needs children and the difficulties they encounter

2. have an understanding of provision of special education in Hong Kong

3. develop relevant intervention strategies using technology to facilitate student development and enhance learning in primary school years

在學期結束時，學生應該能夠：

1. 了解各類特需兒童的特點和遇到的困難

2. 了解香港提供特殊教育

3. 使用科技發展相關的干預策略，以促進學生的發展和加強小學階段的學習

courses.subject: LDTE
courses.title: Project in Learning Design and Technology
courses.description: This is a two-semester course for final year students of the programme. Under the guidance of project supervisors, students are required to complete an individual project pertaining to the applications of learning, design, and technology in education, workplace, or other organizational settings. They should draw on theoretically-informed and empirically-validated learning design frameworks to design innovative and authentic technology-enriched learning experiences for the participants so that the curricular goals are attained. They should propose a project in the field of Learning Design and Technology and execute that project from analysis to evaluation.
